[HEADING] Project Abstract Summary

[TEXT] This Project Abstract Summary form must be submitted or the application will be considered incomplete. Ensure the Project Abstract field succinctly describes the project in plain language that the public can understand and use without the full proposal. Use 4,000 characters or less. Do not include personally identifiable, sensitive or proprietary information. Refer to Agency instructions for any additional Project Abstract field requirements. If the application is funded, your project abstract information (as submitted) will be made available to public websites and/or databases including USAspending.gov.

[TEXT] Funding Opportunity Number HRSA-26-004

[TEXT] CFDA(s) 93.224

[TEXT] Applicant Name

[TEXT] ALETHEIA HOUSE INC

[TEXT] Descriptive Title of Applicant's Project

[TEXT] A comprehensive program that provides integrated primary care and behavioral health to individuals who are experiencing homelessness in western Jefferson County.

[HEADING] Project Abstract

[TEXT] The Bessemer Neighborhood Health Center (BNHC), operated by Aletheia House since March 2017, proposes to continue providing comprehensive, community based primary health care services in western Jefferson County, Alabama. The service area includes the city of Bessemer and surrounding areas, which account for approximately 30% of Alabama's population experiencing homelessness. BNHC serves individuals, who present with barriers that prevent them from getting health care, including those facing housing instability and financial hardship. In 2024, 96.2% of patients lived at or below the federal poverty level, and 73.7% were uninsured. The health center provides general medical care, chronic disease management, behavioral health services, and patient support services through a fixed clinic and a mobile health unit. Patients present with high rates of chronic conditions including obesity, hypertension, diabetes, and hepatitis C, as well as mental health and substance use disorders. To address barriers like transportation, financial strain, and limited familiarity with the health system, BNHC offers transportation assistance, case management, and outreach services. Services are tailored to meet the needs of all age groups and are delivered regardless of ability to pay. BNHC collaborates with local hospitals, shelters, and specialty providers to ensure continuity of care. The proposed project will continue to meet the needs of its service area through integrated services and coordinated partnerships.

[HEADING] Project Narrative

[TEXT] Need

[TEXT] 1. Describe the proposed service area (consistent with Attachment 1: Service Area Map and Table), including:

[HEADING] a. The Service Area boundaries

[TEXT] The Bessemer Neighborhood Health Center (BNHC) is funded by Healthcare for the Homeless (HCH) program funding. The service area is located in western Jefferson County, Alabama. It is bordered by Bibb County to the south, Tuscaloosa County to the west, Shelby County to the east, and northern Jefferson County to the north. The service area includes zip codes within the Birmingham-Hoover Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[TEXT] These boundaries were defined based on patient residence data, community health indicators, and the geographic reach of BNHC's clinic and mobile health unit. The service area reflects where patients live and where services are actively delivered, ensuring that BNHC remains responsive to the needs of the target population.

[HEADING] b. If it is located in an Opportunity Zone

[TEXT] The BNHC service area includes Census Tract 102, which is designated as a federally recognized Opportunity Zone. The tract is located within the 35020 zip code in Bessemer, Alabama, and is home to approximately 3,000 residents. The median household income in this tract is $31,019 and nearly 47% of the population lives below the poverty line.

[TEXT] BNHC's location within this tract allows the health center to serve individuals in a community where economic conditions may contribute to limited access to healthcare. The health center's fixed site and mobile unit are positioned to provide consistent and reliable services to residents in this zone and surrounding areas, helping to address gaps in care and improve access to essential health services.

[TEXT] c. How the boundaries of the service area ensure that services are available and accessible to the residents of the area

[TEXT] The boundaries of the BNHC service area were established based on patient residence data, community health indicators, and input from local organizations. The area includes zip codes where BNHC has consistently served patients through both its fixed clinic and mobile health unit.

[TEXT] The health center's clinic is centrally located within the service area and allows for walk-in access for many patients. For individuals who face challenges reaching the clinic, like lack of transportation or distance, BNHC offers transportation services to and from appointments. Additionally, the health center operates a mobile health unit that travels to shelters, transitional housing programs, and other community-based locations. The mobile outreach allows BNHC to

[TEXT] address barriers in reaching services in areas where access to care is limited. BNHC also offers telehealth options to accommodate patients that are unable to attend in-person visits.

[TEXT] By aligning the service area boundaries with the locations where patients live and where services are actively delivered, BNHC ensures that care remains accessible to individuals throughout, including those who may otherwise be disconnected from traditional healthcare settings.

[TEXT] d. How the overlap of political subdivisions, school districts, and areas served by Federal and State health and social programs affect access to primary health care services in the service area

[TEXT] The service area covers multiple zip codes in Jefferson County, including areas within the cities of Bessemer and Birmingham. These areas fall under different political subdivisions and school districts, and there are differences in social programming available, all which impact access to healthcare services.

[TEXT] Bessemer and Birmingham operate independently, each with their own municipal government and public services. This separation means differences in resource allocation, infrastructure development, and public transportation availability.

[TEXT] The service area also overlaps with several school districts including Bessemer City Schools, Birmingham City Schools, and Jefferson County Schools. Some of the schools have limited school-based health services through external providers, while others do not offer school-based health services. This limits access to care for students in parts of the service area.

[TEXT] Federal and state programs like Medicaid, SNAP, and housing assistance are active in the area, but many residents still face barriers to accessing primary care due to provider shortages, transportation limitations, and gaps in coordination between health and social services. BNHC works to address these challenges by coordinating with local shelters, housing programs, and community organizations to ensure patients are connected to care and support services.

[TEXT] This overlap in the area can make it harder for residents to navigate where and how to get care. BNHC helps bridge gaps by offering consistent, community-based care to individuals who may otherwise be disconnected from traditional healthcare systems.

[TEXT] e. How you will annually review the proposed service area to identify where your patients reside, available health resources, and unmet need

[TEXT] The health center reviews its service area annually by analyzing patient address data, Uniform Data System (UDS) reports, and county-level health indicators. This process identifies where patients reside, evaluates the availability of local health and social services, and highlights unmet need.

[TEXT] BNHC also incorporates feedback from quarterly patient advisory committee meetings and surveys to better understand barriers to care and gaps in services. These findings are used to adjust outreach strategies, strengthen partnerships, and ensure the service area continues to align with community needs. The goal is to ensure that the service area continues to reflect where patients live and where services are most needed.

[TEXT] f. If your urban/rural selection on Form 1A is different from the service area type listed for the proposed area on the SAAT, explain why, including data sources

[TEXT] Not applicable.

[TEXT] g. Using Uniform Data System (UDS) data, describe changes to the service area since your last SAC application

[TEXT] Since the last SAC application, BNHC has continued to serve patients across western Jefferson County, Alabama, with consistent reach across zip codes. While there has been a slight shift in the service area boundaries, they remain aligned with where patients reside, as confirmed through annual reviews of UDS data and patient records. The most recent analysis shows that over 75% of patients continue to reside within the designated service area zip codes.

[TEXT] UDS data and health indicators reflect a growing need for more intensive services. BNHC patients continue to present with high rates of chronic conditions and behavioral health diagnoses. In 2024:

[TEXT] · 96.2% of patients lived at or below 100% of the Federal Poverty Level.

[TEXT] · 73.7% were uninsured.

[TEXT] · Nearly 50% had a substance use disorder diagnosis.

[TEXT] · Over 70% had a mental health diagnosis.

[TEXT] · Rates of hypertension, obesity, and hepatitis C remain elevated compared to national averages.

[TEXT] The service area continues to face economic instability with high rates of unemployment and disability, and limited transportation. These are barriers to accessing care and highlight the importance of BNHC's services, such as the mobile health unit and transportation support, and partnerships with shelters and community organizations.

[TEXT] The number of patients served varies year to year, likely due to the transient nature of the target population. The complexity of patient needs remains steady. BNHC has responded to these needs by maintaining consistent service delivery, strengthening referral coordination, and continuing outreach. The health center remains focused on meeting the needs of its target population through accessible, community-based care.

[TEXT] 2. Describe health care needs in the announced service area, including those that you are meeting or which are met by the current Health Center Program award recipient. If your service area includes, HP, RPH, and/or MSAW funding, include the needs of the special medically underserved population. Address needs related to:

[TEXT] a. Comprehensive primary health care services, including in-scope nutrition, chronic disease management, preventive health education, cancer screening, and mental health services

[TEXT] BNHC provides comprehensive primary health care services to individuals experiencing homelessness and others in western Jefferson County. The health center offers general medical care, preventive screenings, chronic disease management, and behavioral health services. These

[TEXT] 3

[TEXT] Aletheia House H80CS30711

[TEXT] services are delivered through a fixed clinic and a mobile health unit that operates in various community locations such as shelters, treatment centers, and transitional housing programs.

[TEXT] UDS data from 2024 shows that BNHC patients experience high rates of chronic conditions:

[TEXT] · 57.5% are diagnosed with obesity

[TEXT] · 28.5% with hypertension

[TEXT] · 12.5% with diabetes

[TEXT] · 9.6% with hepatitis C

[TEXT] These rates are significantly higher than national averages for Health Care for the Homeless (HCH) programs, indicating a strong need for ongoing chronic disease management and preventive care. BNHC addresses these needs through routine screenings, lab services, and patient education focused on managing long-term conditions.

[TEXT] Mental health and substance use disorders are also prevalent, with 73.4% of patients have a mental health diagnosis and 49.3% have a substance use disorder. BNHC provides outpatient behavioral health services, including screening, counseling, and medication-assisted treatment (MAT) for opioid use disorder.

[TEXT] b. Patient support services (for example, services that enable patients to access health center services, health and nutrition education services, and case management and care coordination services that can address health-related social factors such as those related to food insecurity, housing insecurity, and financial strain).

[TEXT] BNHC provides a variety of patient support services that help patients access care and manage their health. To help patients reach appointments, BNHC offers transportation assistance, including rides to and from the clinic. The mobile health unit also plays a key role in reaching individuals who may not be able to travel to the clinic.

[TEXT] Case management is provided by a medical social worker who helps patients navigate available health and social services. This includes assistance with applications for programs such as Medicaid, SNAP, and disability benefits, as well as referrals to housing support and other community resources. The social worker also helps patients coordinate follow-up care and manage treatment plans.

[TEXT] BNHC staff provide basic health education during visits, including information about managing chronic conditions and understanding prescribed medications. While formal nutrition counseling is not currently offered in-house, patients with specific dietary needs are referred to external providers.

[TEXT] These support services are designed to reduce barriers and help patients stay engaged in care. BNHC continues to assess patient needs through surveys, advisory committee feedback, and community input to ensure services remain responsive and accessible.

[TEXT] In addition to the high prevalence of chronic diseases and behavioral health diagnoses among the patient population, other factors impact health status and access to primary care services in the area.

[TEXT] Economic instability and employment barriers-Western Jefferson County continues to experience elevated rates of unemployment and underemployment. 96.2% of BNHC live at or below the federal poverty line and 73.7% of the patients are uninsured. These rates are significantly higher than the national average for FQHCs, including the average for Healthcare for the Homeless FQHCs. Patients that do work often obtain low-wage, seasonal, or informal jobs that do not offer health insurance or paid time off, limiting their ability to seek care. BNHC patients often report financial strain, which contributes to delayed care-seeking and poor management of chronic conditions.

[TEXT] Housing Insecurity and Transitional Living Situations-Much of BNHC's target population resides in shelters, transitional housing, residential substance use treatment facilities, or other unstable living arrangements. Others are unsheltered individuals. Some of these environments often lack privacy, proper medication storage, and consistent access to transportation which hinder care. BNHC's mobile health unit and transportation services are critical in reaching these individuals and maintaining engagement in care.

[TEXT] Limited Health Literacy and Navigational Challenges-Many patients face challenges such as low health literacy and limited familiarity with the healthcare system, which creates difficulty understanding their diagnoses and available resources. BNHC addresses this need through patient education during visits and case management support, but the demand for linguistically appropriate health education remains high.

[TEXT] Transportation-Despite the central clinic location and mobile outreach, transportation remains a barrier for many patients. Public transit options are limited, and many individuals lack access to personal vehicles. BNHC's transportation assistance services help address this gap, but the need is still significant.

[TEXT] Limited Access to Telehealth-BNHC patients often lack cellphones, internet access, and even digital literacy. This limits the effectiveness of remote care options and underscores the importance of in-person and mobile services.

[TEXT] Dental Care-Feedback from patients and community partners has indicated a significant need for dental care. Many patients report difficulty obtaining preventive and routine dental services due to cost, transportation barriers, and lack of providers that offer services to those with public insurance or no insurance. This need contributes to poor oral health outcomes, which are closely linked to health status and chronic disease management. BNHC works to address this challenge through its mobile dental unit and referral partnerships.

[TEXT] BNHC is committed to addressing the array of needs impacting health status and primary care services through community-based care, strategic partnerships, and ongoing assessment of barriers to health and wellness.

[TEXT] Increased Demand for Integrated Behavioral Health Services-The local health care system has seen a rise in demand for integrated behavioral health and substance use disorder services, driven by increased awareness and the ongoing opioid crisis. BNHC's MAT program and outpatient counseling services are experiencing higher utilization, and the health center is exploring partnerships to expand capacity and reduce wait times.

[TEXT] Persistent Workforce Shortages and Provider Access Barriers-Jefferson County is designated as both a Primary Care and Mental Health Professional Shortage Area (HPSA). These designations indicate a shortage of providers relative to the needs of the residents. The mental health provider ratio is 410:1, the national average is 320:1. Primary care availability is similarly strained, particularly for uninsured and low-income individuals. Many local practices have long waitlists, limited appointment availability, and do not accept uninsured patients or offer sliding fee scales. These shortages affect BNHC's patient population, 73.7% of which are uninsured. This contributes to delayed care, fragmented treatment, and increased reliance on emergency departments for non-urgent needs.

[TEXT] 5. Describe the following aspects of your sliding fee discount program policies:

[TEXT] a. How you assess all patients for sliding fee discount eligibility based only on income and family size. See income definition in Chapter 9: Sliding Fee Discount Program of the Compliance Manual.

[TEXT] The health center applies a sliding fee discount program uniformly to all patients for all required and additional health services within the HRSA-approved scope of the project. The assessment of sliding fee discount eligibility is based solely on income and family size. Income is defined as revenue that meets the IRS definition for federal taxation, while family size includes individuals living together who share income and consumption of goods, including dependents who receive more than 50% of their financial support from a household member

[TEXT] At the first visit, each patient meets with a staff member who verbally explains the sliding fee discount program in their primary language, with interpretation services provided if needed. Patients receive registration materials, including sliding fee discount eligibility forms, and instructions on completing them. These documents are available in English and Spanish, and interpreter services are offered when required. Signs indicating the availability of the sliding fee discount are posted in accessible and visible locations in English and Spanish.

[TEXT] Patients are requested to provide documentation such as the most recent tax return, pay stubs, proof of unemployment compensation, social security payments, or proof of eligibility for other

[TEXT] 14

[TEXT] Aletheia House H80CS30711



========== PAGE 26 (from PDF footer) ==========

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 242897

[TEXT] Grant Number: 6 H80CS30711-09-04

[TEXT] income-based government assistance (e.g., Medicaid, TANF, SNAP). Patients can self-declare their income through a signed statement if they lack access to documentation.

[TEXT] b. How you adjust patient charges based on the ability to pay (consistent with Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule).

[TEXT] Patient charges are adjusted solely based on the patient's ability to pay through a sliding fee discount scale, which includes differing flat fee amounts that are graduated according to income categories. Patients with higher incomes are charged higher fees, and these flat fees are not based on the actual cost of the service. The sliding fee discount is available only to patients with incomes at or below 200% of the Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG). Patients with incomes above 200% of the FPG are not eligible for discounts. The sliding fee discount schedule is updated annually to reflect the most recent Federal Poverty Guidelines.

[TEXT] Patients eligible for sliding fee discounts who also have third-party coverage are charged no more for out-of-pocket costs (e.g., deductibles, co-pays, services not covered by the plan) than they would pay under the applicable sliding fee discount pay class. Fees for contracted services are collected by BNHC using the sliding fee discount process, and contractors are prohibited from collecting fees.

[TEXT] c. Whether you have a nominal charge for patients with incomes at or below 100% of the Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG). If so, describe how the amount is nominal from the perspective of the patient and would not reflect the actual cost of the service being provided.

[TEXT] Patients that are living at or below 100% of the Federal Poverty Guidelines are not charged fees.

[TEXT] d. How you evaluate your sliding fee discount program to ensure that it reduces financial barriers to care.

[TEXT] The sliding fee discount program is evaluated annually and every three years to ensure it effectively reduces financial barriers to care. For the annual review, the sliding fee discount scales are updated to reflect the latest Federal Poverty Guidelines. During the triennial review, utilization data is collected to assess the rate at which patients in each discount pay class, as well as those at or below 100% of the FPG, access services. Data from patient satisfaction surveys and focus groups are also used to evaluate the program's effectiveness in reducing financial barriers.

[TEXT] Based on these evaluations, the Bessemer Neighborhood Health Center identifies and implements necessary changes to the sliding fee program. The Board of Directors reviews and updates the sliding fee discount annually and approves procedures for fee waivers. All agreements are reviewed by the Executive Director before execution to ensure compliance with the sliding fee discount schedule.

[HEADING] c. Aligns with the needs of the underserved populations in the area.

[TEXT] The health center's services are made to meet the needs of the population it serves in the area, primarily those that are experiencing homelessness. Additionally, many of the patients in the area face transportation, financial, or language barriers. BNHC offers transportation assistance, mobile health services, a sliding fee scale, and enabling services such as case management and eligibility assistance. These supports ensure that care is responsive to social and structural challenges in that impact health.

[TEXT] 7. Describe your process to ensure continuity of care for patients. Include:

[TEXT] a. Communication tools, referral processes, and electronic exchange of patient health records.

[TEXT] Continuity of care is established through a coordinated system that includes communication tools, structured referral processes, and electronic health records (EHR). The EHR is a robust system used to document patient visits, track health outcomes, and facilitate communication among care team members. This system supports real-time access to patient records and enables secure electronic exchange of information with referral partners.

[TEXT] Referral processes are standardized and managed by the patient services coordinator and medical social worker, who assist patients with scheduling, transportation, and follow-up. BNHC maintains formal agreements with external providers and monitors referral outcomes through direct communication and documentation. These processes ensure that patients receive timely, coordinated care across settings.

[HEADING] b. Hospital admitting privileges.

[TEXT] BNHC has a memorandum of understanding (MOU) in place with a local hospital, Medical West, to support continuity of care for patients who require hospitalization. While BNHC's physician does not hold direct hospital admitting privileges, coordination with Medical West allows for appropriate referral and follow-up when patients are admitted

[TEXT] c. Receipt, follow-up, and recording of medical information from referral sources.

These partnerships include local public housing authorities, resident associations, social service agencies, faith-based organizations, and other healthcare providers. Partners also help distribute information about BNHC's sliding fee scale, transportation assistance, and mobile health unit schedule. These efforts ensure that residents are informed about their care options and can access services that meet both their medical and social needs.

[TEXT] 4. How your financial accounting and internal control systems, and policies:

[TEXT] a. Ensure effective control over all health center funds, property, and other assets.

[TEXT] The Chief Financial Officer and accounting staff of Aletheia House utilize a financial management system and internal control system that reflects Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) for non-profit health centers or Government Accounting Standards Board (GASB) principles for public health centers. This system ensures effective control over all health center funds, property, and other assets. At minimum, this includes: 1) ensuring all Bessemer Neighborhood Health Center expenditures are consistent with the HRSA-approved total budget and with any additional applicable HRSA approvals that have been requested and received; 2) effective control over, and accountability for, all funds, property, and other assets associated with the Health Center Program project; 3) safeguarding of all assets to assure they are used solely for authorized purposes in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Health Center Program award/designation; and 4) tracking the financial performance of the Health Center, including identification of trends or conditions that may warrant action by the organization to maintain financial stability. The Chief Financial Officer ensures that Bessemer Neighborhood Health Center's financial management system is able to account for all federal awards in order to identify the source and application of funds for federally funded activities. Specifically, Bessemer Neighborhood Health Center's financial records will contain information and related source documentation pertaining to authorizations, obligations, unobligated balances, assets, expenditures, income, and interest under Federal awards.

[HEADING] b. Track the financial performance of the health center.

[TEXT] Financial performance is tracked continuously by the CFO and her team. This includes managing the draw-down of federal funds to ensure it is in compliance with grant standards and has appropriately met the financial goals set at the beginning of the grant/program year.

[TEXT] c. Separate accounting for this award from other federal awards, including documentation of the receipt and expenditure of SAC funds.

[TEXT] Aletheia House maintains separate accounting for all grant programs. Grant funds for the project will receive a fund code that is known to all involved in the spending and reconciling of grant funds. Funds are coded to the appropriate account and reviewed by Aletheia House accounting staff. An annual financial audit by a third-party agency is performed each year to ensure appropriate separate accounting procedures have been followed.

[TEXT] 5. Your experience and plans for maintaining continuity of services and responding to urgent primary health care needs during natural or man-made disasters and public health emergencies. Your response should be consistent with all applicable Federal, state, and local laws and regulations.

[TEXT] BNHC has an established emergency preparedness plan that outlines policies and procedures for maintaining continuity of services and responding to urgent primary health care needs during natural or man-made disasters and public health emergencies. The plan includes preparation, response, and recovery protocols that are reviewed and updated regularly to ensure alignment with federal, state, and local regulations.

[TEXT] The health center maintains backup systems, including emergency generators and technology redundancies, to support uninterrupted operations. Patient records are managed through an electronic health record system that can be accessed securely from multiple locations, ensuring continuity of care even if the primary site is disrupted.

[TEXT] BNHC coordinates with the local health department to stay informed of public health guidance and response protocols. During emergencies, the health center prioritizes care for with complex medical needs or limited access to other providers, and deploys its mobile health unit when needed to reach individuals who may be displaced or unable to visit the fixed clinic. Staff are trained annually on emergency procedures, and the plan includes clear communication strategies to ensure coordination across departments and with external partners.

[TEXT] 6. Competing continuation applicants: Citing your UDS data for the number of unduplicated patients served in calendar year 2024, describe factors that have affected your patient trend since your last SAC application. Explain any downward trend in your total unduplicated patients.

These resources supported initiatives such as increased mobile unit deployment and expanded virtual care options, which helped reach individuals who may not have otherwise received care.

[TEXT] Since that time, the expiration of supplemental funding has limited BNHC's ability to sustain those expanded efforts. Additionally, fluctuations in the local population served by BNHC may have impacted patient volume. According to the local HUD Continuum of Care, the annual Point-in-Time counts of individuals experiencing homelessness have varied over the past five

[HEADING] Impact/Evaluative Measures

[TEXT] 1. Describe how your Quality Improvement/Quality Assurance (QI/QA) program:

[TEXT] a. Follows clinical guidelines and standards of care.

[TEXT] BNHC's Quality Improvement/Quality Assurance (QI/QA) program is led by the Clinical Director and is structured to ensure that services are delivered in accordance with current clinical guidelines and standards of care. The Clinical Director works with the QI/QA Committee to review and update protocols based on evidence-based practices and regulatory requirements. Staff are trained to follow these guidelines, and adherence is monitored through regular chart reviews and data analysis.

[TEXT] The health center uses its electronic health record system to collect and track clinical data, including UDS measures. This data is reviewed during monthly QI/QA meetings to assess performance and identify areas for improvement. When gaps are identified, the team develops and implements new processes or workflows to improve care delivery. This approach ensures that BNHC maintains high standards of clinical quality and remains responsive to patient needs and program expectations.

[HEADING] b. Addresses patient safety.

[TEXT] Patient safety is a core component of BNHC's Quality Improvement and Quality Assurance (QI/QA) program. The Clinical Director leads monthly QI/QA meetings where patient safety data, including adverse events, is reviewed to assess performance and identify areas for improvement. When safety concerns or incidents are identified, the QI/QA Committee works with the Clinical Director to determine appropriate follow-up actions. Staff are trained to implement these actions, and the electronic health record system is used to document and monitor whether follow-up care is provided as directed. BNHC fosters a culture of safety by encouraging staff to report concerns without fear of retaliation and by continuously reviewing protocols to minimize risk and prevent harm.

[HEADING] c. Improves patient experience and satisfaction.

[TEXT] BNHC improves patient experience and satisfaction by actively collecting and responding to patient feedback. The Director of Growth and Quality Performance gathers input through patient satisfaction surveys, quarterly Patient Advisory Committee meetings, and surveys from community stakeholders. This feedback is reviewed by the Health Center Director, Clinical Director, and QI/QA Committee to identify areas for improvement and guide service modifications. Patients may also report grievances directly to leadership, and unresolved concerns can be escalated to the QI/QA Committee for review. These processes ensure that patient voices are central to how services are evaluated and refined.

[TEXT] 2. Describe how you will improve clinical quality and health outcomes within your patient population, including within the following specified areas:

[TEXT] BNHC will improve clinical quality and health outcomes by continuing to implement its QI/QA plan, which includes monthly data reviews, targeted interventions, and staff training. Patient feedback and performance metrics are used to guide service modifications. The health center will also strengthen referral coordination and expand use of at-home monitoring tools to support chronic disease management and early intervention. The health center has been successful in improving clinical quality and health outcomes, leading to an award for BNHC's efforts.

[HEADING] a. Body Mass Index (BMI) screening and follow-up plan

[TEXT] BNHC conducts BMI screenings for all patients during routine visits. When BMI falls outside the recommended range, providers initiate follow-up plans that may include nutrition education, physical activity counseling, and referrals to external providers for specialized support.

[TEXT] b. Breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer screenings

[TEXT] BNHC tracks cancer screening eligibility through its EHR and provides screenings in-house when possible. For services not offered on-site, such as mammograms and colonoscopies, patients are referred to partner organizations. Staff assist with scheduling and follow-up to ensure completion and documentation of results.

[HEADING] c. Diabetes and hypertension control

[TEXT] BNHC monitors patients with diabetes and hypertension through regular visits and at-home monitoring tools. Care plans include medication management, lifestyle counseling, and referrals to external providers when needed. Data is tracked through the EHR to assess control rates and guide interventions.

[TEXT] d. Screening for depression and follow-up planning, including depression remission

[TEXT] All patients are screened for depression using standardized tools. When a positive screen is identified, BNHC initiates a follow-up plan that may include counseling, behavioral health referrals, and medication management. Progress is monitored through follow-up assessments and documented in the EHR.

[HEADING] Governance

[TEXT] 1. Describe how your governing board reflects the community you serve and how board members engage with patients to ensure that the health center is responsive to patient needs. Reference Form 6A: Current Board Member Characteristics

[TEXT] BNHC solely receives funding under the Healthcare for the Homeless program. Because of HCH funding, the health center operates under a governance waiver, as documented in Form 6B, due to its integration within a larger organizational structure. While the agency's Board of Directors oversees policies and strategic direction for the organization as a whole, BNHC maintains a separate Patient Advisory Committee (PAC) to ensure representation from the community served by the health center.

[TEXT] The PAC is composed of individuals who reflect the demographics and lived experiences of BNHC's patient population, including individuals experiencing homelessness and individuals who receive services at the health center. The committee meets quarterly to provide feedback on service delivery, identify barriers to care, and recommend improvements. Input from the PAC is shared with health center leadership and used to inform operational decisions and quality improvement efforts. BNHC ensures compliance with HRSA governance requirements through documented PAC engagement, regular reporting to the Board, and alignment of PAC recommendations with strategic planning. This structure ensures that BNHC remains responsive to patient needs while maintaining compliance with governance requirements under the waiver.

[HEADING] ALETHEIA HOUSE, INC. BY-LAWS

[HEADING] ARTICLE I. MISSION

[TEXT] Section 1.1 The mission of Aletheia House is to empower individuals, and the communities in which they live, with the skills and services they need to be responsible for their own well-being. Services provided by the organization to achieve this mission shall include, but not be limited to: 1) quality, affordable, and accessible healthcare, 2) substance abuse treatment and prevention services, and 3) decent housing that is affordable to low and moderate income individuals.

[HEADING] ARTICLE II. PRINCIPAL OFFICE

[TEXT] Section 2.1 The corporate office of this corporation shall be in Jefferson County, Alabama or at any other place in the State of Alabama so designated from time to time by the Board of Directors.

[HEADING] ARTICLE III. AUTHORITIES, FUNCTIONS AND REPSONSIBILITIES OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS

[TEXT] Section 3.1 The Board of Directors shall be the governing authority responsible for overseeing the mission, direction and effective management of the affairs of the corporation. The authorities, functions, and responsibilities of the Board of Directors shall include, but not be limited to:

[TEXT] Holding monthly meetings and maintaining minutes and other records that verify and document the board's functioning.

[TEXT] · Approving applications related to the organization's health center project, including grant applications, designation applications and other HRSA requests regarding scope of project.

[TEXT] . Approving applications related to the organization's social services and housing including grants and low-income housing tax credit applications. Approving financial policies and procedures.

[TEXT] . · Approving the organization's annual budget, the health center's annual budget, and annual independent audit of financial accounts, records and resources.

[TEXT] · Approving contracts of every kind for any lawful purpose with any person, firm, association or corporation in the furtherance of the purpose of the organization.

[TEXT] · Reviewing the organization's target population and service area periodically, and updating the organization's by-laws and governing board as needed to respond to changes.

[TEXT] · Authorizing the acquisition, management and disposition of all property and physical facilities.

[TEXT] · Allocating assets and resources.

[TEXT] · Approving and receiving gifts or bequests of land, buildings, bonds, stocks, monies, annuities and other devices for Aletheia House in accordance with the corporation policy and donor intent.

[TEXT] · Receiving appropriate information (e.g. health center patient satisfaction data, QI/QA information, the results of the annual audit) that enables it to evaluate the health center's progress, and using this information to engage in a long-term strategic planning process that includes regularly updating the health center's mission, goals, and plans when appropriate.

[TEXT] · Approving the organization's long-term strategic plan.

[TEXT] · Setting organizational priorities.

[TEXT] · Monitoring the organization's performance in meeting its annual and long-term goals (e.g. clinical, financial, operational).

[TEXT] · Evaluating patient/consumer and employee satisfaction.

[TEXT] · Establishing one or more health centers that will provide integrated medical care, behavioral health care, and supportive services.

[TEXT] · Selecting services that will be provided at the health centers beyond those required in law to be provided by the organization, as well as the location and mode of delivery of those services.

[TEXT] · Determining the hours during which services shall be provided at each of its health center sites, and ensuring these hours are appropriate and responsive to the community's needs.

[TEXT] · Approving the selection and/or dismissal the organization's Executive Director, and performing annual appraisals of his/her performance.

[TEXT] · Establishing general policies and procedures for the organization consistent with HRSA's Health Center Program regulations and applicable grants management requirements. Specific health center policies and procedures that will be approved and monitored by the Board include, but are not limited to: board member selection and dismissal procedures, employee salary and benefit scales, employee grievance procedures, equal opportunity practices, codes of conduct, quality improvement system, fee schedules for services, the sliding scale discount program, billing and collections, financial policies that assure accountability for health center resources, and avoidance of conflict of interest.

[HEADING] ARTICLE IV. BOARD MEMBERSHIP

[TEXT] Section 4.1 The Board of Directors shall consist of twenty-one voting members. Directors shall be elected from nominees who are screened by the nominating committee. No member shall be an employee or an immediate family member (i.e. spouse, child, parent, brother, or sister by blood, adoption or marriage) of an employee. The Executive Director shall serve as a non-voting, ex-officio of the Board.

[TEXT] Section 4.2 At least eleven of the board members shall be individuals who receive services at the organization's health centers. These individuals will be known as "patient board members".

[TEXT] No more than one-half of the non-patient board members shall derive more than ten percent of their annual income from the health care industry.

[HEADING] ARTICLE VI. SELECTION AND REMOVAL OF BOARD MEMBERS

[TEXT] Section 6.1 Board members shall be elected for a three year term. The election of officers and directors shall occur in December, expect that a vacant position may be filled at any board meeting. Board members may serve consecutive three year terms.

[TEXT] Section 6.2 The Board President shall appoint a nominating committee which shall be responsible for recruiting and screening potential board members. Nominations to the board will be made when a vacancy occurs or when the term of a board member ends. The committee will be responsible for nominating a sufficient number of qualified individuals who are patients, homeless and/or public housing residents as board members to meet the organization's board membership requirements.

[TEXT] Section 6.3 A director who has missed three consecutive meetings, without good cause, may be removed by a unanimous vote the board members attending a regular or special board meeting. In addition, a director may be removed by the unanimous vote of the board members attending a regular or special meeting whenever the board believes, in its judgment, the best interest of the corporation will be served by the removal of a director. Removal will only be effective when all directors, including those who may be removed, have received notice in writing and/or email at least five days prior to the meeting that a vote has been scheduled to remove one or more director.

[HEADING] ARTICLE VII. ELECTION OF OFFICERS

[TEXT] Section 7.1 The officers of the corporation shall be President, Vice-President, Secretary and Treasurer. The Board of Directors will elect these officers for a one-year term from its membership, and such officers shall serve at the pleasure of the board. Officers may serve re- elected to sequential one-year terms.

[TEXT] Section 7.2 The Board of Directors shall elect officers at its August meeting by majority vote. A majority of the board members may remove an officer at any time prior to the termination of the designated term.

[HEADING] ARTICLE VIII. RECORDING, DISTRIBUTION AND STORAGE OF MINUTES

[TEXT] Section 8.1 Minutes of all meetings of the Board of Directors, Executive Committee, and other committee meetings indicating the time and place of the meeting, whether the meeting was regular or special, the Directors in attendance, and the proceedings of the meeting (including actions taken on any motions) will be maintained in a permanent file and stored in the corporate office. Copies of these minutes will be distributed to Board members, in writing and/or by email, within fourteen days.

[HEADING] ARTICLE IX. MEETING SCHEDULE AND QUORUM

[TEXT] Section 9.1 Meetings of the Board of Directors shall be held monthly. In those cases where, in the opinion of the Board President, geography or other circumstances make monthly, in-person board meeting burdensome, monthly meetings may be conducted by telephone or other means of electronic communication where all parties can both listen to, and speak to, all other parties.

[TEXT] Section 9.2 Special meetings of the Board of Directors may be called by the President or upon petition to the President by one-quarter of the board members. Directors shall receive five days written notice stating the time, place and purpose of any special meeting. At such special meetings, only such business as is stated in the call for such meeting shall be transacted.

[TEXT] Section 9.3 One-third of the Board of Directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. While the board may meet informally without the presence of a quorum, no official action of the organization may take place without the presence of a quorum of board members attending in-person, by telephone or by other electronic communication method where all parties can both listen to, and speak to, all other parties.

[TEXT] ARTICLE X. OFFICER RESPONSIBILITIES, TERMS OF OFFICE AND SELECTION/ REMOVAL PROCESS

[TEXT] Section 10.1 The responsibilities of the officers shall include:

[HEADING] President

[TEXT] The president shall preside at all meetings. He or she shall sign all official documents and contracts pertaining to the corporation, except that the board may grant to the Executive Director limited authority to execute certain documents on behalf of the corporation. He or she will appoint members to standing and ad hoc committees.

[HEADING] Vice-President

[TEXT] The Vice-President shall assume the duties of the President in the President's absence.

[HEADING] Secretary

[TEXT] The Secretary shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of minutes of all proceeding of the board. He or shall may sign, where required, corporate papers in conjunction with the President.

[HEADING] Treasurer

[TEXT] The Treasurer shall ensure all books and accounts are accurately kept, and a full and detailed financial statement, properly audited by an independent certified public accountant, is presented to the board annually. He or she shall also ensure that an annual budget and regular financial statements are presented to the Board. He or she shall serve as the Chair of the Finance Committee.

[HEADING] Section 10.2 The terms of officers shall be one year.

[TEXT] Section 10.3 The Nominating Committee shall nominate one or more directors to serve in each of the officer position. Directors also make nomination for officers from the floor. In the event more than one director is nominated for an officer position, the directors present shall vote by secret ballot with the member who receives the highest number of votes being elected to the position.

[TEXT] Section 10.4 An officer who has missed three consecutive meetings, without good cause, may be removed by a vote of a majority of the board members attending a regular or special board meeting. In addition, an officer may be removed by a majority vote of the board members attending a regular or special meeting whenever the board believes, in its judgment, the best interest of the corporation will be served by the removal of an officer. Removal will only be effective when all directors, including those who may be removed, have received notice in writing and/or email at least five days prior to the meeting that a vote has been scheduled to remove one or more officer.

[HEADING] ARTICLE XI. COMMITTEES

[TEXT] Section 11.1 Standing Committees will include the Executive, Finance, Quality Improve- ment/Quality Assurance, and Planning and Nominating Committees. The President will assign each board member to one or more standing committee. One half of the committee's membership shall constitute a quorum.

[HEADING] Executive Committee

[TEXT] The Executive Committee shall be comprised of the President, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer, and the past-President (if he or she remains a current board member).

[TEXT] The Board of Directors shall authorize the Executive Committee to act on its behalf when, in the opinion of the President or two Executive Committee members other than the President, it is in the best interest of the corporation to take actions prior to a meeting of the full governing board. The actions of the Executive Committee shall not supersede the full governing board's authorities, functions and responsibilities. The Executive Committee shall report all actions taken independently, and on behalf of the board, to the full governing board which shall vote on these actions are report them in the board minutes.

[TEXT] The Executive Committee shall be responsible for performing an annual performance appraisal of the Executive Director and making recommendation to the full governing board regarding his or her compensation. The Board of Directors shall vote to approve, modify or reject the Executive Committee's performance appraisal and compensation recommendation.

[HEADING] ARTICLE XII. CONFLICT OF INTEREST

[TEXT] Section 12.1 The Board of Directors shall prohibit conflicts of interests by board members. A conflict of interest shall exist when a board member or his or her immediate family (i.e. spouse, child, parent, brother, or sister by blood, adoption or marriage), has an existing or potential financial interest which might impair, or might reasonably appear to impair, the member's independent, unbiased judgment in the discharge of his/her responsibilities to the corporation.

[TEXT] Any member who has a conflict of interest shall declare this conflict. Any member who is uncertain if he or she has a conflict of interest, or if another member may have a conflict, shall notify the person chairing the meeting of the potential conflict of interest. A majority vote of the board members attending the meeting shall determine if a conflict of interest exists.

[TEXT] No member shall vote on any matter, under consideration at a board or committee meeting, in which such member has a conflict of interest.

[TEXT] The meeting minutes shall reflect that a disclosure of a conflict of interest, or a vote determining there is a conflict of interest, was made and that the member having the conflict of interest abstained from voting.

[TEXT] Section 12.2 The Board of Directors shall prohibit conflicts of interest, real or apparent, among board members, employees, consultants, and those who furnish goods or services to the health

[TEXT] Section 12.4 No part of the net earnings of the organization shall inure to the benefit of any member, founder, contributor or individual. The organization shall not be under the control or direction of any individual or entity seeking to derive profit or gain.

[HEADING] ARTICLE XIII. DISSOLUTION

[TEXT] Section 13.1 The Corporation may be dissolved by a majority vote of a meeting of the Board of Directors, provided that written notice shall be provided to each board member at least ten days prior to a vote to dissolve the corporation. Any assets that remain in the corporation after providing for debts, obligations, and liabilities of the corporation shall be distributed to one or more non-profit organizations that provide healthcare and which have established their tax exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Service Code, or the corresponding provision of any future United States law.

[HEADING] ARTICLE XIV. INDEMNIFICATION

[TEXT] Section 14.1 Each member shall be indemnified against all expenses reasonably incurred by such member in connection with the defense of any action, suit or proceeding to which he or she has been made a party by reason of being, or having been, a board member, except where such member shall be adjudicated to be liable for gross neglect or willful misconduct in connection with his or her performance as a member.

[TEXT] The position of chief financial officer (CFO) is responsible for all financial matters of Aletheia House. The CFO will oversee all compliance and recognition for government (federal and state) contracts and local/private grants. [TEXT] Position Summary:

[TEXT] The nurse practitioner (NP)/clinical director will work for the Aletheia House - Bessemer Neighborhood Health Clinic seeing patients in-person and via telemedicine. The patient population will be adults with chronic, acute and/or complex medical conditions, especially those who are experiencing homelessness. The NP/CD will be required to work independently in the clinic setting - seeing patients and billing independently. The workload will consist of evaluating/examination of patients, implementing treatment plans, and follow up of plans and education. The NP/CD will develop and implement programs best suited for special populations and be responsible for tracking of outcomes. The ideal candidate has experience either as an NP in a Federally Qualified Health Clinic or outpatient clinic setting. The following NPs may be considered for this role: Family NP, Adult Primary NP

[HEADING] Primary Responsibilities:

[TEXT] -To provide medical care and treatment within established scope of practice to medical services patients as assigned by and under the direction of the collaborating physician (Section 610-X-5 of the Alabama Board of Nursing Administrative Code) or under supervision of a Board Certified Physician (Section 540-X-7 of the Alabama Board of Medical Examiners Administrative Code).

[TEXT] -To provide leadership in Health Center's initiatives of best patient outcomes and practice efficiency and effectiveness; this includes but is not limited to: developing programs for improved patient treatment plans, conducting staff meetings, helping prepare and participate in grant audits, and working closely with the Health Center's Director on any Health Center objectives.

[TEXT] -To coordinate plan of care, discharge and specialty referrals as appropriate to meet the age specific needs of the patient.

[TEXT] -To plan and coordinate health care education for patient, family and other health care providers as needed.

[HEADING] Biographical Sketch Chris Retan Executive Director

[TEXT] Chris Retan has served as the Executive Director of Aletheia House since 1983, after initially being hired as the Administrative Coordinator in 1978. With over 45 years of experience in nonprofit administration, he has led the organization's growth into one of Alabama's largest providers of behavioral health services and affordable housing for low-income individuals and families. Under his leadership, Aletheia House has developed a national reputation for delivering high-quality, evidence-based services to underserved populations.

[TEXT] Chris provides oversight and reports to the Board of Directors for the organization's Federally Qualified Health Center (FQHC), which operates a Healthcare for the Homeless program. Under his guidance, the health center has a proven track record of providing comprehensive, accessible healthcare services to vulnerable populations, ensuring compliance with Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) regulations and demonstrating measurable outcomes in quality of care.

[TEXT] Throughout his tenure, Chris has secured extensive federal funding for various projects through agencies such as the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and HRSA, among others. He has successfully implemented these programs, ensuring compliance with federal regulations and achieving high levels of performance.

[TEXT] Chris holds a Bachelor's Degree in Education from the University of Minnesota and a Master's Degree in Public Administration from the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB). He has also completed the Executive Education Certificate Program in Strategic Planning for Nonprofit Organizations at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government.

[TEXT] Beyond his leadership at Aletheia House, Chris has served as an adjunct faculty member in UAB's Master of Public Administration program, where he taught nonprofit management. His contributions to the field have been recognized with the Administrator of the Year Award from the Alabama Chapter of the American Society for Public Administration.

[TEXT] With decades of experience working with low-income individuals, veterans, and those experiencing homelessness, Chris is deeply committed to serving underserved populations. His expertise ensures that Aletheia House's programs and services are designed to meet the unique needs of vulnerable communities across Alabama, including those served by the FQHC and its Healthcare for the Homeless program.

[HEADING] Biographical Sketch Gloria Howard

[HEADING] Chief Operating Officer

[TEXT] Ms. Howard is the Chief Operating Officer of Aletheia House. She has 38 years of social service experience, which includes 25 years in management level positions at Aletheia House. Her responsibilities include the development and implementation of the agency's treatment and prevention programs, including ensuring that the agency's services are appropriate for the largely African American population served by the agency.

[TEXT] She has been the Project Director for several federally funded projects which focused on low- income African Americans including: 1) Men of Honor- a SAMHSA-funded substance abuse treatment and HIV prevention program for African-American men returning to the community from jail prison; 2) Mother's Hope- a SAMHSA-funded substance treatment and prevention program for pregnant and postpartum African American women, 3) Women's Hope- a SAMHSA-funded substance-abuse treatment and HIV prevention program for African-American women; 4) Power to Change- a SAMHSA-funded substance abuse and HIV program for African American men; 5) Ebony Pearls- African American women who are living with HIV or who are at high risk for HIV infection, and 6) Healthy Living, a SAMHSA-funded substance abuse treatment and HIV prevention program for African-American men and women living in rural Alabama.

[TEXT] She has served on the faculties of the Alabama School of Alcohol and Drug Studies, the Tennessee School of Alcohol and Drug Studies, the African American Community Summit on HIV/AIDS, and the Alabama Alliance to End Homelessness. She has made presentations regarding the design and implementation of culturally competent services for the Center of Substance Abuse Prevention, Center for Substance Abuse Treatment and Department of Labor.

[TEXT] A Certified Prevention Manager, Ms. Howard supervises a summer prevention program that received recognition from the Department of Justice as a model program to reduce and prevent drug use, gang involvement, and violence among African American children and adolescents living in low-income communities. She also serves as an Advisor for the Birmingham Board of Education's Safe and Drug Free Schools Committee.

[TEXT] Ms. Howard has a bachelor's degree from Alabama State University in criminal justice and a Master's degree in counseling and human development from Troy University. She completed the Executive Education Certificate Program in Non-Profit Management at Harvard University's Kennedy's School of Business. In addition, she has completed coursework towards a master's degree in Public Administration from the University of Alabama at Birmingham. She is also an Internationally Certified Advanced Alcohol and Drug Professional.

[TEXT] In 1999, the Alabama Council of Community Mental Health Board named Ms. Howard "Substance Abuse Professional of the Year."

[HEADING] Biographical Sketch Tavaneka McKisson

[HEADING] Chief Financial Officer

[TEXT] Tavaneka McKisson is the Chief Financial Officer for Aletheia House. She has over 25 years of accounting experience, including over 15 years of accounting for a community college, six years with Aletheia House, one year as the treasurer for the City of Bessemer and 7 years as the independent contractor for a non-profit.

[TEXT] Her accounting duties and responsibilities have included: supervising a staff of over 20 administrative support and professional staff, preparing G5 System drawdowns of federal grants, developing and implementing internal controls to ensure greater separation of duties, maintaining a schedule of audits, developing policies and procedures for fiscal affairs, and preparing and managing a college-wide budget of over 45 million dollars. Mrs. McKisson also has extensive experience in preparing financial reports required by various federal agencies including the U.S. Department of Education, he U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, the U.S. Department of Labor, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, the U.S. Department of Veteran Affairs, and the Health Resource and Service Administration.

[HEADING] Biographical Sketch Lindsey Rice Bender Associate Director of Operations

[TEXT] Dr. Lindsey Rice Bender is the Associate Director of Operations at Aletheia House. She has over 10 years in nonprofit administration and management, including over 3 years providing operational oversight to federally qualified health centers. In this role, Dr. Rice Bender oversees the agency's federally qualified health center for the homeless, substance misuse prevention programs, program expansion, and program evaluation. She plays a crucial role in ensuring operational, financial, and contract compliance for the health center, aligning all aspects with project requirements. Her responsibilities include addressing accountability, implementing policies, and managing risk effectively. Her work contributes to the agency's mission of providing high-quality, accessible services to underserved populations.

[TEXT] Beyond her leadership at Aletheia House, Dr. Rice Bender serves as an adjunct faculty member in UAB's Master of Public Health program, where she teaches programs and policies, a course focused on how to use evidence of community needs to identify and prioritize public health programs and policies designed to improve community health, reduce disease, and promote healthy living.

[TEXT] Dr. Rice Bender's work focuses on the expansion of community-based healthcare, the treatment and prevention of maternal substance use disorders, and the prevention of adolescent substance misuse. Dr. Rice Bender holds a Bachelor of Arts in Medicine, Health and Society from Vanderbilt University, a Master of Public Health in Maternal and Child Health from the University of Alabama at Birmingham, and a Doctor of Public Health in Maternal and Child Health from the University of Alabama at Birmingham.

[TEXT] Biographical Sketch Jordain Boland

[HEADING] Health Center Director

[TEXT] Jordain Boland serves as the Health Center Director at Aletheia House's Bessemer Neighborhood Health Center, where she oversees integrated behavioral health, substance use disorder treatment, and primary care services for individuals with limited access to health care in Jefferson County, Alabama. With over 15 years of experience in community-based behavioral health, she has held roles as a therapist, program manager, and treatment coordinator.

[TEXT] Ms. Boland specializes in clinical compliance and program development. Her work emphasizes the integration of behavioral and physical health services while addressing social risk factors such as housing instability, economic hardship, and geographic barriers to care. She leads efforts to improve access to whole-person care through interdisciplinary collaboration and community partnerships.

[TEXT] She holds dual Bachelor's degrees in Psychology and Human Ecology (Nutrition) from Tennessee Technological University and a Master's degree in Counseling from Walden University, with a specialization in Secondary Injury. Ms. Boland is a Certified Advanced Alcohol and Drug Counselor (AADC) and an Associate Licensed Counselor (ALC). Her additional certifications include Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT), Post- Adoption Attachment (Portland State University), and Collaborative Problem Solving.

[HEADING] Health Center Program Compliance

[HEADING] Sliding Fee Discount Program

[TEXT] Describe:

[HEADING] · How the sliding fee discount program applies uniformly to all patients.

[TEXT] BNHC's sliding fee discount program is applied uniformly to all patients, regardless of insurance status or service type. Eligibility is determined solely based on income and family size, and all patients are assessed during their initial visit and annually thereafter. The discount schedule is aligned with current Federal Poverty Guidelines and includes multiple pay classes for patients between 100% and 200% of FPG. Patients at or below 100% FPG receive a full discount or a nominal charge, as outlined in Attachment 10.

[HEADING] · Definitions of income and family size used.

[TEXT] BNHC defines income using the standard applied for federal income tax purposes. Family size is defined as individuals related by blood, marriage, or legal adoption who reside in the same household and share financial resources

[TEXT] · How eligibility is assessed based only on income and family size.

[TEXT] All patients are assessed for sliding fee discount eligibility based solely on their income and family size. The process is conducted in a respectful and efficient manner that maintains patient privacy and confidentiality. Staff explain the program clearly and provide assistance with completing required forms, ensuring the assessment is accessible and consistent for all patients.

[HEADING] · Alignment with current Federal Poverty Guidelines.

[TEXT] BNHC's sliding fee discount schedule is based on the most recently published Federal Poverty Guidelines and is updated annually to ensure continued alignment. The schedule includes full discounts for patients at or below 100% of FPG, partial discounts for those between 101-200% of FPG, and no discounts for patients above 200% of FPG.

[HEADING] · How patient charges are adjusted based on ability to pay.

[TEXT] BNHC adjusts patient charges based on documented income and family size, using a sliding fee discount schedule aligned with the current Federal Poverty Guidelines. Patients eligible for discounts are asked to provide verification, which may include tax returns, pay stubs, unemployment statements, Social Security or disability payments, or proof of eligibility for income-based assistance programs. Patients experiencing homelessness may self-declare income through a signed statement. No patient is denied services due to inability to pay.

[TEXT] · Whether a nominal charge is used for patients at or below 100% FPG, and how it is determined.



========== PAGE 98 (from PDF footer) ==========

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 242897

[TEXT] Grant Number: 6 H80CS30711-09-04

[TEXT] BNHC applies a nominal charge of $5.00 for patients with incomes at or below 100% of the Federal Poverty Guidelines. This amount is established by the Board of Directors and is considered nominal from the patient's perspective, as it does not reflect the actual cost of services. Patients experiencing homelessness are not charged a fee.

[HEADING] Contract and Subawards

[TEXT] Describe:

[HEADING] · Oversight of contracts and subawards.

[TEXT] BNHC does not make subawards. All external arrangements are structured as contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project. Oversight of these contracts is guided by board- approved policies and includes provisions for monitoring contractor performance, accessing contractor records and reports, and ensuring compliance with federal financial and programmatic reporting requirements. The Executive Director is responsible for determining when contracted services are appropriate and for structuring agreements accordingly. All contracts are reviewed and approved by the Board of Directors prior to execution.

[TEXT] · How Health Center Program requirements are applied to subrecipients.

[TEXT] There are no subrecipients for this program.

[TEXT] · How costs are monitored for allowability under federal cost principles.

[TEXT] BNHC ensures that all costs are allowable under federal cost principles through a multi-step review process. Staff authorized to expend funds are trained on the terms and conditions of the federal award and applicable cost principles. All expenditures are reviewed and approved by the Chief Financial Officer or a trained accountant under her supervision, prior to payment to confirm allowability and compliance.

[HEADING] Billing and Collections

[TEXT] Describe:

[HEADING] · Participation in Medicare, Medicaid, CHIP, and other programs.

[TEXT] During intake, patients are asked to provide third-party insurance information. For patients who are eligible but not enrolled, the medical social worker assists with benefit applications and enrollment.

[HEADING] · Board-approved policies for waiving or reducing fees based on inability to pay.

[TEXT] BNHC implements a sliding fee discount program supported by board-approved policies and procedures that ensure fees are reduced or waived based on a patient's ability to pay. During intake, income is verified through documentation or self-declaration (for patients experiencing



========== PAGE 99 (from PDF footer) ==========

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 242897

[TEXT] Grant Number: 6 H80CS30711-09-04

[TEXT] homelessness), and patients are informed of their applicable charges. No patient is denied services due to inability to pay.

[HEADING] Governance: Board Authority

[TEXT] Describe:

[TEXT] · Where in Attachment 2: Bylaws the following are documented:

[TEXT] :unselected: o Monthly meetings- Section 3.1 and 9.1

[TEXT] Selection/dismissal of PD/CEO- Section 3.1

[TEXT] :unselected: Approval of budget, applications, services, locations, and hours- Section 3.1

[TEXT] :unselected: o Evaluation of health center performance- Section 3.1

[TEXT] o Policy establishment- Section 3.1

[TEXT] :unselected: Compliance with laws and regulations- Section 3.1

[TEXT] · Confirm that no other entity or committee has veto power over the board.

[TEXT] The Board of Directors is the governing authority responsible for overseeing the mission, direction and effective management of the affairs of Aletheia House. Aletheia House's organizational structure and documents do not allow for any other individual, entity or committee (including, but not limited to, an executive committee authorized by the board) to reserve approval authority or have veto power over the board regarding the required authorities and functions. This organizational structure is documented in Aletheia House policies and bylaws

[HEADING] · Confirm that collaborations do not restrict board authority.

[TEXT] In cases where Aletheia House's BNHC collaborates with other entities in fulfilling the health center's HRSA-approved scope of project, these collaborations and/or agreements with the other entities do not restrict or infringe upon the health center board's required authorities and functions. The principles governing this requirement are outlined in Aletheia House's policies and bylaws.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of triennial needs assessment update using current data, addressing access/utilization factors, morbidity/mortality, and unique health needs.
compliantItems.evidence: "BNHC conducts a comprehensive needs assessment every three years—it was last updated in September 2025—which includes a full analysis of service area demographics, health indicators and patient diagnoses using UDS data and county-level health statistics. It also includes and input from patients and community partners. This assessment is used to identify gaps in care, barriers, and emerging health trends, and serves as a tool for strategic planning and service delivery."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates a needs assessment updated at least every three years, using current data, and addressing access/utilization, morbidity/mortality, and unique health needs. (1) Frequency is SATISFIED: the application states the needs assessment was last updated in September 2025 and is conducted every three years. (2) Use of results is SATISFIED: the assessment is used for strategic planning and service delivery. (3) All required data elements are addressed with explicit, recent data and sources. All Must Address items are satisfied with direct evidence; requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of board-approved sliding fee discount program policies that apply uniformly to all patients and address definitions of income/family, eligibility assessment, SFDS structure, and nominal charge requirements.
compliantItems.evidence: "BNHC's sliding fee discount program is applied uniformly to all patients, regardless of insurance status or service type. Eligibility is determined solely based on income and family size, and all patients are assessed during their initial visit and annually thereafter. The discount schedule is aligned with current Federal Poverty Guidelines and includes multiple pay classes for patients between 100% and 200% of FPG. Patients at or below 100% FPG receive a full discount or a nominal charge, as outlined in Attachment 10."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates board-approved sliding fee discount program policies that apply uniformly and address four specific areas. We checked: (1) definitions of income/family - SATISFIED: explicit definitions provided, (2) assessment based only on income/family size - SATISFIED: process described, (3) SFDS structure based on ability to pay - SATISFIED: schedule and adjustment method detailed, (4) nominal charge for ≤100% FPG - SATISFIED: $5 charge described as nominal, with further waiver for homeless patients. All items are explicitly addressed with direct quotes and referenced attachments/policies. Therefore, the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of the Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (SFDS) for Column I services to ensure full discount (or nominal charge) at/below 100% FPG, partial discounts with at least three pay classes between 101-200% FPG, and no discounts above 200% FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: "Aletheia House Sliding Fee Scale Based on 2025 Federal Poverty Guidelines... 0% -100% Poverty... $5.00... >100-125%... $14.00... >125%-150%... $20.00... >150%-175%... $27.00... >175%-200%... $35.00... Above 200%... NO DISCOUNT"
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates: (1) a full discount or nominal charge at/below 100% FPG, (2) partial discounts with at least three pay classes between 101-200% FPG, and (3) no discounts above 200% FPG. The SFDS table on Page 93 shows a $5 nominal charge for ≤100% FPG, four graduated discount classes between 101-200% FPG ($14, $20, $27, $35), and 'NO DISCOUNT' above 200% FPG. The narrative confirms the $5 charge is nominal and that discounts are structured by income class. All three must-address items are explicitly satisfied; therefore, the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities

compliantItems.evidence: "The health center collaborates with local hospitals, shelters, and specialty providers to ensure continuity of care. "The health center collaborates with local hospitals to reduce non-urgent use of hospital emergency departments and improve continuity of care for patients. "BNHC collaborates with a wide range of community partners to increase awareness of available services and address health-related needs across the service area. All three items are satisfied: (1) continuity of care is addressed through partnerships and referral agreements, (2) access to community services is documented via collaborations with social service agencies and housing authorities, and (3) reduction in non-urgent ED use is addressed through established referral pathways with local hospitals. Therefore, the requirement is compliant.
