compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center has bylaws or other documents specifying the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members, and that no outside entity, committee, or individual (other than the board) can select the board chair or majority of board members.
compliantItems.evidence: "Section 6.1 Board members shall be elected for a three year term... Section 6.2 The Board President shall appoint a nominating committee which shall be responsible for recruiting and screening potential board members... Section 6.3 A director who has missed three consecutive meetings, without good cause, may be removed by a unanimous vote the board members attending a regular or special board meeting. In addition, a director may be removed by the unanimous vote of the board members attending a regular or special meeting whenever the board believes, in its judgment, the best interest of the corporation will be served by the removal of a director."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit bylaws or documents describing the process for selection and removal of board members, and that only the board may select the board chair or majority of members. We checked: (1) selection/removal process - SATISFIED: bylaws detail nomination, election, and removal by board action; (2) restriction on outside entities - SATISFIED: bylaws and narrative confirm no other entity or committee has authority over board selection or removal. All items are satisfied with direct, explicit evidence; requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of HRSA compliance for waiver of patient majority board composition requirements, including demonstration of good cause and alternative mechanisms for patient input.
compliantItems.evidence: "The population to be served are individuals experiencing homelessness. it would be difficult to identify and recruit a majority of board members who have the skills needed to effectively manage the organization who are themselves individuals experiencing homelessness." "The board has attempted to identify and recruit members who have the skills needed to manage the board who have themselves previously experienced homelessness. There are currently 5 board members who have previously experienced homelessness." "The board has established a patient advisory committee that provides and opportunity for patient to provide feedback to improve services. This committee specifically includes patients experiencing homelessness. the health center also regularly conducts patient surveys so all patients have the opportunity to provide suggestions for improvement."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates demonstration of good cause for the waiver (including unique population/service area characteristics and recruitment attempts) and strategies for ensuring patient participation in governance. (1) Good cause is SATISFIED: The application explicitly describes the challenges in recruiting a patient majority from the homeless population and documents attempts to recruit such members. (2) Alternative mechanism is SATISFIED: The application details a Patient Advisory Committee with direct patient input, including those experiencing homelessness, and regular patient surveys. Both must address items are fully satisfied with direct, explicit evidence in Form 6B. Therefore, the requirement is compliant.
